failure_modes.description: Liking someone makes you ignore their flaws
failure_modes.real_world_case: Elizabeth Holmes - investors liked her, ignored red flags at Theranos.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If you can't name 3 flaws, you're probably biased

failure_modes.description: Promoting liked people over qualified ones
failure_modes.real_world_case: Family businesses failing due to unqualified family members in leadership.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Liked candidates should still meet 80% of objective criteria

failure_modes.description: Liking things associated with liked people
failure_modes.real_world_case: Celebrity endorsements - liking celebrity transfers to product regardless of quality.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Celebrity endorsement adds 0 information about product quality

failure_modes.description: Being manipulated by those who flatter you
failure_modes.real_world_case: CEOs surrounded by yes-men making poor decisions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If no one disagrees with you, you're not getting honest feedback

failure_modes.description: Favoring those similar to you
failure_modes.real_world_case: Homogeneous boards and teams missing diverse perspectives.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Teams with < 30% diversity underperform on complex problems

failure_modes.mode: Dismissing good ideas from disliked sources
failure_modes.description: Rejecting valid information because of who says it
failure_modes.real_world_case: Political polarization - dismissing opponent's valid points.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Good ideas are equally valid regardless of source

failure_modes.description: Seeking evidence to confirm negative views
failure_modes.real_world_case: Short sellers becoming blind to positive developments in hated companies.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If you can't name 3 positives about disliked entity, you're biased

failure_modes.description: Conflicts escalate due to mutual dislike
failure_modes.real_world_case: Business feuds destroying value for both parties.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Conflict costs typically exceed 'winning' benefits by 3-5x

failure_modes.description: Losing valuable people due to interpersonal dislike
failure_modes.real_world_case: Key employees leaving due to personality conflicts with leadership.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Replacing key talent costs 150-200% of annual salary

failure_modes.description: Missing opportunities in disliked sectors/companies
failure_modes.real_world_case: Value investors missing tech because they disliked the sector.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Disliked sectors can outperform for decades

failure_modes.description: Deciding too quickly to avoid uncertainty
failure_modes.real_world_case: Snap judgments in hiring leading to poor fits.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Important decisions should have minimum 24-hour delay

failure_modes.description: Claiming certainty that doesn't exist
failure_modes.real_world_case: Financial forecasts presented as certain when highly uncertain.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Most forecasts should have Â±20% uncertainty ranges

failure_modes.description: Sticking with decisions to avoid doubt
failure_modes.real_world_case: Sunk cost fallacy - continuing failing projects to avoid admitting error.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Review major decisions quarterly with kill criteria

failure_modes.description: Accepting expert opinion to avoid own doubt
failure_modes.real_world_case: Following analyst recommendations without own analysis.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Expert consensus is wrong 30-40% of the time on complex issues

failure_modes.description: Forcing complex issues into yes/no to avoid doubt
failure_modes.real_world_case: Investment decisions as all-in or nothing, missing position sizing.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Most decisions have 5+ reasonable options, not just 2

failure_modes.description: Refusing to change views despite new evidence
failure_modes.real_world_case: Kodak leadership refusing to accept digital photography threat.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If you haven't changed a major view in 2 years, you're not learning

failure_modes.description: Small commitments leading to large ones
failure_modes.real_world_case: Gradual ethical compromises leading to fraud.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Small compromises compound - review trajectory quarterly

failure_modes.description: Views become part of identity, impossible to change
failure_modes.real_world_case: Political identity preventing objective policy evaluation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If changing view would feel like betrayal, it's identity-based

failure_modes.description: Appearing consistent even when wrong
failure_modes.real_world_case: Leaders doubling down on bad strategies to appear consistent.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Changing mind on evidence is strength, not weakness

failure_modes.description: Past decisions constraining future options unnecessarily
failure_modes.real_world_case: QWERTY keyboard - suboptimal but locked in by consistency.
warning_signs: We've always done it this way
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Review 'constraints' annually - many are self-imposed

failure_modes.description: Endless research preventing action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Academics who research forever but never publish or act.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 80% of value comes from first 20% of research

failure_modes.description: Learning that doesn't translate to action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Reading business books without implementing anything.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Learning without application has < 10% retention

failure_modes.description: Curiosity pulling attention from priorities
failure_modes.real_world_case: Entrepreneurs distracted by new ideas instead of executing current ones.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Switching costs are 20-30 minutes per context switch

failure_modes.description: Investigating trivia instead of important questions
failure_modes.real_world_case: Investors researching company trivia instead of key drivers.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 5 key questions drive 80% of decision quality

failure_modes.description: Using research to avoid difficult action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Researching investments instead of making them.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Time in market beats timing the market over 10+ years

failure_modes.description: Choosing fair but suboptimal outcomes
failure_modes.real_world_case: Equal pay regardless of performance destroying incentives.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Performance-based systems outperform equal systems by 20-40%

failure_modes.description: Rejecting unfair but beneficial offers
failure_modes.real_world_case: Rejecting acquisition offers because terms feel unfair.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Any gain > 0 is better than no gain from spite

failure_modes.description: Being exploited through fairness appeals
failure_modes.real_world_case: Negotiations lost by anchoring on 'fair' split instead of value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Fair is often defined by whoever speaks first

failure_modes.description: Treating unequal things as equal for fairness
failure_modes.real_world_case: Giving equal time to unequal arguments in debates.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Equal treatment of unequal things is unfair

failure_modes.description: Fair process producing unfair outcomes
failure_modes.real_world_case: Meritocracy that ignores starting point inequality.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Fair process with unfair outcomes is still unfair

failure_modes.description: Spending based on others' consumption
failure_modes.real_world_case: Lifestyle inflation destroying wealth accumulation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Comparison spending can reduce savings rate by 50%+

failure_modes.description: Chasing returns others have achieved
failure_modes.real_world_case: FOMO buying at market tops after seeing others' gains.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Performance chasing reduces returns by 2-4% annually

failure_modes.description: Undermining others due to envy
failure_modes.real_world_case: Workplace politics destroying team performance.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Toxic envy can reduce team performance by 30-50%

failure_modes.description: Focusing on what others have, ignoring own blessings
failure_modes.real_world_case: Wealthy people unhappy because others are wealthier.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Hedonic adaptation means more never feels like enough

failure_modes.description: Choosing careers based on others' success
failure_modes.real_world_case: Following hot careers without fit, leading to burnout.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Career fit matters more than prestige for long-term success

failure_modes.description: Being influenced by gifts or favors
failure_modes.real_world_case: Pharmaceutical company gifts influencing doctor prescriptions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Even small gifts ($10) measurably influence decisions

failure_modes.description: Revenge cycles destroying value
failure_modes.real_world_case: Business feuds escalating to mutual destruction.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Revenge typically costs more than the original harm

failure_modes.description: Others exploiting your reciprocation tendency
failure_modes.real_world_case: Free samples creating purchase obligation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Unsolicited favors create no genuine obligation

failure_modes.description: Returning more than received
failure_modes.real_world_case: Giving expensive gifts in response to small favors.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Reciprocation should be roughly proportional

failure_modes.description: Building up obligations that constrain future action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Political favors creating compromising obligations.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Favor debts compound - clear them quickly

failure_modes.description: Blaming bearer of bad news
failure_modes.real_world_case: Executives punishing those who report problems, hiding issues.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Organizations that shoot messengers fail 3x more often

failure_modes.description: Positive view of things associated with liked things
failure_modes.real_world_case: Stanford dropout founders getting funded based on school association.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Prestigious associations add noise, not signal

failure_modes.description: Negative view based on associations
failure_modes.real_world_case: Good companies avoided because of industry association.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Individual quality varies widely within any category

failure_modes.description: Automatic responses to associated stimuli
failure_modes.real_world_case: Buying on good news, selling on bad news without analysis.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Automatic responses are wrong 40-60% of the time

failure_modes.description: Judging based on past associations that no longer apply
failure_modes.real_world_case: Avoiding reformed companies based on past problems.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Reassess associations every 2-3 years

failure_modes.description: Refusing to accept business is dying
failure_modes.real_world_case: Blockbuster denying streaming threat until bankruptcy.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 3 years of decline is pattern, not anomaly

failure_modes.description: Refusing to accept own weaknesses
failure_modes.real_world_case: Founders refusing to hire professional management.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Everyone has 3-5 major weaknesses - know yours

failure_modes.description: Refusing to accept past investments are lost
failure_modes.real_world_case: Continuing failed projects because of past investment.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Sunk costs are sunk - only future costs and benefits matter

failure_modes.description: Ignoring partnership or team dysfunction
failure_modes.real_world_case: Co-founder conflicts ignored until company fails.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Unaddressed conflicts grow 10x worse over time

failure_modes.description: Ignoring customer/market signals
failure_modes.real_world_case: Products failing because founders denied negative feedback.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If customers leave, there's a real problem to address
